page.title: 15The Local History of Whiston
page.content: 1920s. The doctor came out to Whiston by horse and trap. The lanes which were roads for the villagers were very busy with horses and carts going down to Froghall station with milk in churns which were loaded on to trains. In the 1930s a bus service started on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays which went to Leek and then on to Cheadle. Mr Harrison, when interviewed, said it seemed to snow more often in the past than now. In 1947 the snow was up to the telegraph poles. There were no bread deliveries so people had to walk to Cheadle to fetch sacks of loaves. In the school there were dances on Saturday nights and concert parties. An agricultural show had a Queen and attracted many people to the village.
